title: Essential Physics
requirements:
1. For JUPAS entrants without attending HKDSE Physics or Combined Science with Physics component, including absentees.
2. For non-JUPAS students, please seek advice and permission from the Department of Physics.
description: This course covers the essential concepts of physics in mechanics, heat, electricity and magnetism, waves, atoms, and nuclei. It aims to bring out the essential concepts and their relevance, using simple mathematics. Secondary school physics and calculus are not required. It is suitable for students in physical sciences, biological and medical sciences, and earth science who lack the basic physics training in secondary school, and for students in other majors who want to learn the essential concepts of physics for their later courses.

title: General Physics
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHYS1111 or 1113.
description: This introductory physics course covers selected topics in mechanics, thermodynamics, electricity, and modern physics. This is a non-calculus-based course, but some algebra and trigonometry will be used. This course is designed for students with HKDSE Physics or HKDSE Combined Science with a physics component. It is suitable for students in the physical sciences, biological and medical sciences, earth science, and for those in other majors who want to learn some basic concepts of physics for their later courses. Students with HKDSE Physics, or a good preparation in HKDSE Combined Science with a physics component and HKDSE Mathematics, who want to major in Physics, may benefit more from taking PHYS1111 or PHYS1113.

title: General Physics for Engineers
description: This non-calculus-based course covers some essential concepts in mechanics, heat, electricity and magnetism. It is designed for engineering students to get an overview on what physics is about. Selected topics include: Newton’s laws of motion, Archimedes’ principle, fluid flow, temperature and heat, laws of thermodynamics, electric field and potential, current and circuits, and electromagnetic waves. The course is suitable for Engineering students without HKDSE physics or Combined Science with a physics component, or with permission of instructor.

title: Exploring the Physical World with STEM
description: (UGEB1506 is double-coded with PHYS1004.) The course aims at revealing the fundamental role that physics principles have been playing in the development of science and technology (S&T), which has drastically changed our ways of living and understanding of nature. Successful stories on the evolution of S&T in human history are introduced in the perspectives of STEM, i.e., from the discovery of fundamental Scientific (Physics) (S) principles, to applying the principles to Technological (T) innovations, solving Engineering (E) problems to make the applications viable, and with Mathematics (M) as the essential language that encompasses the whole process. Modern technology is also shown to change the ways of modern scientific investigation and accelerate human understanding of the physical world in an unprecedented speed. Science related social issues are used to help students understand the importance of using science principles and knowledge in making judgements and informed decisions. Lively demonstrations, lab visit, and STEM activities are used in class to (1) illustrate basic physics principles, (2) make physics principles more connected to students’ daily life applications, and (3) better prepare students for explaining science concepts and conducting basic educational STEM activities as an educator, publisher, reporter, and in other S&T related disciplines in the future. Secondary school physics are not required to take this course.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to:  Explain and apply some fundamental physics principles in non-technical terms.  Create, plan, and conduct basic STEM education activities related to physics and explain the underlying principles.  Explain and exemplify the interplay between science and technology, especially on how fundamental physics principles have evolved into innovative applications that changed the world, and how the advance in technology has accelerated our understanding of nature.  Recognize and appreciate the generality and beauty of physics principles and be aware of its working in nature, its impacts on technology and daily life.  Recognize and appreciate mathematics as the language of physical sciences and its fundamental role in all forms of engineering.  Analyze scientific information in public media and popular science contexts; and think critically on science related issues.  Make judgements and informed decisions based on science principles and knowledge.  Be motivated to learn about science and technology as a part of life-longed learning.
syllabus: Major topics (nos. in […] refer to the references in Section 8):  Motions and Energy: Motion and inertia; Newton’s second law of motion, friction, momentum, applications of these concepts on traffic and road safety; energy and power, and examples including chemical changes in digesting food and explosion; different sources of energy and their environmental impacts [1,2,4,5].   Amazing Fluids: Basic introduction to the concepts of fluids such as density, pressure, viscosity, fluid resistance, diffusion and turbulence; basic principles of flying machines from frisbee to airplane; interactions of fluids with micro-particles, face masks and COVID-19 prevention [1,2,15].  Wonders of Light: Basic geometrical and wave properties of light, reflection, refraction, dispersion, diffraction and interference, and daily life applications; light-atom interactions, emission and absorption spectra, spectrometry and applications; basic principles of laser and its modern applications: optical fibre, laser surgery, optical tweezers, fluorescence imaging; blue LED and applications [1,2,3,9,10,11,12].  Beyond Light: Maxwell’s discovery of electromagnetic waves, electromagnetic spectrum, ionizing and non-ionizing radiations; uses of non-ionizing radiations including communication, temperature measurements, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); applications, hazards, and safety of ionizing radiations.  Ultracold world: Temperature, heat and basic heat transfer mechanisms; change of phases, phase diagram and factors affecting phase changes, change in material properties on cooling, basic concepts on superconductivity and its applications such as magnetic levitation and MRI [1,2,3,5,6,8,9,13,14].   Going Small: Structure of atoms and dual nature of elementary particles, basic quantum phenomena, electrons and electron microscopes, constructing and seeing nanostructures, present and future applications [1,3,4,6,8,9]. Essential skills and concepts taught together with the topics above [4,5,7]:  Educational demonstration experiments and STEM activities for conveying basic physics concepts and the underlying principles of technological applications.  Interpreting and presenting science information in a non-technical way, understanding the degree of confidence of scientific experiments, popularizing science, awareness of the risk of distortion and exaggeration, ethics in conveying science information.  The roles of mathematics in physics and technology are illustrated with exemplars on (1) the importance of precision and accuracy in scientific measurements, (2) how the order of magnitude of physical quantities crucially affect the outcomes of physical phenomena, and (3) how mathematical derivations deliver essential results that go much beyond qualitative understanding.

title: Engineering Physics: Mechanics and Thermodynamics
description: This is an introductory calculus-based engineering physics course covering topics in mechanics and thermodynamics. Topics include: Use of vectors in mechanics, force and motion, free-body diagrams, work and energy, potential energy and conservation of energy, momentum and impulse, torque, essential ideas in rotation, equilibrium, gravitation, ideal fluids, oscillations, waves and sound, elementary concepts of thermodynamics and heat transfer mechanisms. Contents will be supplemented by discussions on applications relevant to engineering. The course is suitable for Engineering students with HKDSE physics or Combined Science with a physics component, or with permission of instructor.

title: Introduction to Mechanics, Fluids, and Waves (University Physics I)
requirements: For New Undergraduate Curriculum from 2012. Not for students who have taken PHYS1113.
description: This introductory calculus-based course discusses the basic principles of mechanics, fluids and waves. The course assumes a background of HKDSE Physics or a good preparation in HKDSE Combined Science with a physics component. It is suitable for potential majors in science and engineering, and for those who intend to minor in physics. Topics include: particle kinematics, force and motion, work and kinetic energy, potential energy, momentum, systems of particles and collisions, rotation, Newton’s law of gravitation, fluid statics and the dynamics of ideal fluids, oscillations, and waves. Students are advised to take this course concurrently with an introductory mathematics course that includes vectors and calculus.

title: Mechanics, Fluids and Waves (University Physics I)
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHYS1111.
description: This introductory calculus-based course discusses the basic principles of mechanics, fluids and waves. The course assumes a good background of HKDSE Physics, Mathematics and Mathematics Extended Part Module 2. It is suitable for potential majors in physics, mathematics and other physical sciences. Topics include: particle kinematics, force and motion, work and kinetic energy, potential energy, momentum, systems of particles and collisions, rotation, Newton’s law of gravitation, fluid statics and the dynamics of ideal fluids, oscillations, and waves. Students are advised to take this course concurrently with an introductory mathematics course that includes vectors and calculus.

[Elementary calculus will be assumed, and only reviewed very quickly.]     2.         Systems of particles   Center of mass, linear momentum, impulse, Newton's second law for a system of particles, collisions.     3.         Rotation   Rotational kinematics, rotational inertia, torque, Newton's second law for rotation, work and rotational kinetic energy, rolling, angular momentum, conservation of angular momentum.     4.         Gravitation   Newton's law of gravitation, gravitational potential energy, Kepler’s laws.     5.         Fluids   Pressure, Pascal's principle, Archimedes' principle, ideal fluids in flow and equation of continuity, Bernoulli's equation.     6.         Oscillations   Simple harmonic motion, energy in a simple harmonic motion, damped oscillation, forced oscillations and resonance.     7.         Waves   Transverse and longitudinal waves, wavelength and frequency, energy of a travelling string wave, superposition, interference of waves, standing waves, sound waves, the speed of sound, intensity and sound level, interference, beats, Doppler’s effect. title: University Physics II – Introduction to Optics and Modern Physics
requirements: For New Curriculum Students.
description: This introductory calculus-based course discusses the basic principles of optics, special relativity, and quantum physics and its applications, plus an introduction to particle physics. The course assumes a background of HKDSE Physics. It is suitable for potential majors in science and engineering, and for those who intend to minor in physics. Topics include: Geometric optics, interference, diffraction, special relativity, quantum physics and its applications to atoms, molecules, solids, and nuclei, particle physics. Students are advised to take this course concurrently with a course in calculus.

principle      2.         Geometric Optics   Reflection and reflection at a plane surface and a spherical surface, thin lenses, some optical instruments     3.         Interference   Interference and the quantum numbers, the Zeeman effect, the electron spin, many-electron atoms and the Pauli exclusion principle, the periodic table, X-ray spectra     10.      Molecules and Solids   Molecular bonds, Nuclear Physics   Some properties of nuclei, nuclear binding and nuclear structure (nuclear force and nuclear models), nuclear stability and radioactivity, decay processes, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, nuclear fusion, biological effects of radiation, (optional) NMR and MRI      12.      Particle Physics and Cosmology   Some particles, positron and antiparticles, particles as force mediator and the meson, particle accelerators and detectors, particles and interactions, finding patterns in particles, quarks, the standard model and beyond, the Cosmic connection (the expanding universe, the big bang, the standard model and the history of the universe)      Learning Outcomes By the end of the course, students will be able to:    1.         describe the basic concepts of optics, special relativity, and quantum physics     2.         analyze and solve basic problems in optics and special relativity     3.         apply the concepts of quantum physics to analyze basic one-dimensional bound state problems     4.         state and appreciate applications of quantum mechanics in microscopic situations      5.         have the necessary background for relevant upper-level courses. outcome: PHY [N] [/N] [T] [/T]     PHYS 1712 - Physics Laboratory I[/T] T1] Course Description    This is a first course in experimental physics, with an aim to help students develop basic skills in performing experimental measurements, handling and utilizing basic equipment, as well as build necessary concepts and attitudes in data and error analysis. The experiments also serve to illustrate the principles and to reinforce the concepts taught in the lecture course PHYS1111.   Grade Descriptors   A : Demonstrate thorough mastery of principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to apply the principles and experimental techniques to familiar and unfamiliar situations, in a manner that would surpass the normal expectation at this level and standards that may be required at higher levels of study or research. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a clear, cogent and possibly creative manner.   A- : Demonstrate substantial command of principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining almost all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques to familiar and some unfamiliar situations, in a manner that is logical and comprehensive. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report with clarity and accuracy.   B : Demonstrate general and sufficient command of the principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining most of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques accurately to most (but not all) familiar and standard situations, in a manner that is logical and persuasive. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a satisfactory and unambiguous way.   C : Demonstrate general command of the principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, in a manner that is not incorrect but is fragmented. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a fragmented but unambiguous way.   D : Demonstrate partial command of principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques to some simple situations only. Has the ability to state the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a simple, fragmented way.   F : Demonstrate little or no evidence of command of the principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining the course learning outcomes, OR failure to meet specified assessment requirements.        Course Status: Core  Course Content        Topics   Highlights of Fundamental Concepts     1     Introductory lecture on the basic principles of data and error analysis in experimental physics for beginning students   Measurements and calibrations; accuracy and precision; meaning of errors; data analysis and error analysis; propagation of errors; basic statistical distributions; linear least square fit; use of Excel for data presentation, error estimation and graph plotting; and format of a scientific report.     2     Laboratory session on ‘Distance measurement with ultrasonic waves’   The physics of ultrasonic waves and their emission, reflection and detection. Use of equipments including ultrasonic emitter and receiver, amplifier and conventional oscilloscope.     3     Laboratory session on ‘Doppler Effect’   Doppler Effect of ultrasonic wave, conservation of energy. Use of equipments including ultrasonic emitter and receiver, amplifier and digital oscilloscope.     4     Laboratory session on ‘Torsional pendulum’   The physics of a torsional pendulum, moment of inertia, dimensional analysis. Measurements using a torsional pendulum with wire & strips.     5     Laboratory session on ‘Frictional force on rolling objects’   The physics of the friction on rolling objects. Measurement of time.     6   Laboratory session on ‘Cavendish's Experiment’   Newton’s universal law of gravitation. The design of Cavendish's famous setup.     7   Laboratory session on ‘Damped oscillator, forced oscillator and resonance’   The physics of damped and forced harmonic oscillators, resonance, solutions of second order differential equation. Use of equipments including LRC circuits, digital oscilloscope, digital multimeter and LRZ meter.     8   Laboratory session on ‘Vibrating string and superposition of waves’   Superposition of waves in a vibrating string, Fourier analysis, forced oscillation, standing wave and resonance. Use of microphone and digital oscilloscope.      Learning Outcomes By the end of the course, students will be able to:    1   Develop general considerations for the design of a scientific experiment title: University Physics III – Introduction to Heat and Electromagnetism
requirements: For New Curriculum Students.
description: This introductory calculus-based course discusses the basic principles of thermodynamics and electromagnetism. The course assumes a background of HKDSE Physics. It is suitable for potential majors in science and engineering. Topics include: the laws of thermodynamics and the kinetic theory of gases; Coulomb’s law, electric field and potential, Gauss’ law, capacitance and dielectrics, current and resistance, DC circuits, magnetic fields, Ampere’s law, Faraday’s law, inductance, AC circuits, Maxwell’s equations and electromagnetic waves.
outcome: PHY 2003 Introduction to Electricity and Magnetism     PHYS 2041 University Physics III Introduction to Heat and Electromagnetism    Course Description    This is an introductory calculus-based course which discusses the basic principles of thermodynamics and electromagnetism.  The course assumes students to have a good background of HKDSE Physics (or equivalent) and calculus.  This course is a core course for physics majors.  Topics include: the laws of thermodynamics and the kinetic theory of gases; Coulomb’s law, electric field and potential, Gauss’ law, capacitance and dielectrics, current and resistance, DC circuits, magnetic fields, Ampere’s law, Faraday’s law, inductance, AC circuits, Maxwell’s equations and electromagnetic waves.   Grade Descriptor   A : Demonstrate thorough mastery of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to apply the principles or subject matter to familiar and unfamiliar situations, in a manner that would surpass the normal expectation at this level and standards that may be required at higher levels of study or research.  Has the ability to express the knowledge or synthesis of ideas in a clear and cogent manner.   A- : Demonstrate substantial command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining almost all the course learning outcomes. (HRW)     1.         Temperature, Heat, and the First Law of Thermodynamics   Temperature and the Zeroth law of thermodynamics, thermometers and temperature scales, thermal expansion of solids and liquids, temperature and heat, specific heat and latent heat, heat and work in thermodynamic processes, internal energy and the First law of thermodynamics with applications, energy transfer mechanisms   Ch. 18     2.         Kinetic Theory of Gases   Molecular model of an ideal gas, pressure and molecular motion, the meaning of temperature, translational kinetic energy, equipartition of energy, mean free path, distribution of molecular speeds, specific heat of an ideal gas, adiabatic processes for an ideal gas   Ch. 19     3.         Entropy and the Second Law of Thermodynamics   Reversible and irreversible processes, irreversible processes and entropy, the Second Law of thermodynamics, engines and refrigerators, the Carnot cycle, efficiency of real engines, microscopic interpretation of entropy   Ch. 20     4.         Electric Charge and Electric Field   Electric charge, conductors and insulators, Coulomb’s law, electric field, electric field calculations (point charge, electric dipole, line of charge, continuous charge distribution), electric field lines, charged particle in an electric field, a dipole in an electric field   Ch. 21-22     5.         Gauss’ Law   Charge and electric flux, Gauss’ Law, applications of Gauss’ Law (cylindrical, planar, spherical symmetries), charged isolated conductor. title: Quantitative Methods for Basic Physics
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH1010 or 1018 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This course provides an introduction to the various analytical techniques necessary for studying physics at university level. Topics include: vectors, rates of change and kinematics, methods for solving ordinary differential equations in mechanics and electric circuits, line integrals and multiple integrals in mechanics, partial differentiation and its applications in mechanics and thermodynamics, methods of vector calculus used in electromagnetism, and applications of infinite series and systems of linear equations in physics.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. demonstrate knowledge in basic mathematical methods in physics2. formulate simple physical problems in mathematical form, and to solve them by mathematical technique, and to interpret the results physically3. recognize the relative importance of different physical quantities, and hence take suitable approximations in mathematical derivations4. identify how various mathematical methods can be combined coherently in describing physical systems and solving physical problems5. appreciate the important role of mathematics in physics, as well as its applications in various areas in physical sciences6. generalize the applications of the mathematical methods learnt in lectures to new situations
syllabus: 1. Transcendental Functions of Complex NumbersLogarithmic and exponential functions of complex numbers; complex trigonometric functions and hyperbolic functions2. Vectors and Related TopicsRepresentations of vectors in different coordinate systems, including cylindrical coordinates and spherical coordinates; motion and trajectory in space; conic sections in polar coordinates; inversion, pseudovectors and pseudoscalars; index notations.3. Applications of CalculusDifferentiation of vectors; central force field problems and solution of planetary motion; Lagrange multipliers; Dirac delta-function.4. Infinite SeriesConvergence and tests of convergence; power series and radius of convergence; Taylor series and approximations, Taylor polynomials for functions of two variables.5. Ordinary Differential Equations - Methods and ApplicationsPhysical examples in mechanics and electric circuits; the method of variation of parameters; the integrating factor method for homogeneous differential equations.6. Matrices and ApplicationsMatrices, orthogonal matrix, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, Gaussian elimination, system of linear equations.7. A quick review of partial differentiationPartial derivatives, total differentials, chain rule, extremum values, Lagrange multipliers.8. Multiple integralsDouble integrals in rectangular coordinates and polar coordinates; triple integrals in rectangular, cylindrical and spherical coordinates; Jacobian of transformation, surface area and integrals over a curved surface.9. Vector calculus, line integral, surface integral and volume integralGradient, divergence and curl; vector operations in various coordinates; physical examples: field flux and divergence theorem, circulation and Stokes’s theorem, conservative fields.

title: Basic Computational Physics
requirements: Not for students who have taken CSCI2800 / 1510 / 1520 / 1110 / 1120. Pre-requisite/Co-requisite: MATH1010 or 1018 or 1520 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This course provides students with the basic knowledge of a few numerical methods and computer programming commonly used to solve problems in physics. Topics include: basic programming skills, interpolation, numerical integration of functions, numerical solution of ordinary differential equations and wave equations. There are computational laboratories for practice, demonstration and illustration of the subject matter. This course, together with PHYS3061 and 4061, provides basic, intermediate and advanced training on this important branch of computational physics. This fundamental course assumes no prior knowledge in computing.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. perform elementary programming in C 2. demonstrate knowledge in basic numerical methods3. employ numerical methods taught and C codes to solve basic physics problems
syllabus: 1. IntroductionPrograming languages, program structures and version control.2. C: Basic conceptsVariables, Expressions and statements, operators, Input/Output, compiling and running the first C program.3. C: Control logic and iterationIf-else and switch statements, for, while, do…while, break and continue statements.  4. C: Functions and program structureBasics of functions, scope rules, header files, block structure.5. C: Arrays and pointersData structures and arrays, array definition and initialization. The concept of pointers, pointer assignment, dereferencing, indexing.6. Numerical methods: InterpolationLagrange interpolation, Neville’s algorithm, Runge phenomenon, Chebyshev polynomials & nodes, Gibbs phenomenon.  7. Numerical methods: Integration of functions Trapezoidal rule, Simpson’s rule, improper integrals, Gauss-Legendre integration.8. Numerical methods: Ordinary differential equationsEuler method, Richardson extrapolation, Taylor method, Runge-Kutta method, boundary value problems, the shooting method.9. Numerical methods (optional): Wave equations and Monte Carlo methods Finite difference approximation to a PDE, Monte Carlo integration, importance sampling and hypothesis testing.

title: Introduction to Astronomy and Astrophysics
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGEB2401 or UGEB2402.
description: The course aims at introducing basic concepts of astronomy and astrophysics, assuming only a secondary school physics and mathematics background. It is designed not only to present a volume of knowledge, but also to arouse students’ curiosity in how nature works. Topics include: the universe at different scales, the Earth and the sky, lunar phases, tides and eclipses, the rise of modern astronomy, theory of motion and gravitation, relativity, the solar system, measuring stars, birth of stars, structure of stars, post-main-sequence evolution, the death of stars, neutron stars, black holes, galaxies and cosmology. Optional activities, for examples, star-gazing trips and visits, may be arranged.

description: This course, together with PHYS1712, aims to introduce basic skills in performing experimental measurements, handling and utilizing basic equipments; and build necessary concepts and attitudes of data and error analysis. Course Status: Core (2 units) Course Content        Topics  Highlights of Fundamental Concepts    1   Laboratory session on ‘Interference and diffraction of light’  Wave nature of light, interference and diffraction. Use of lasers and photodetectors.    2   Laboratory session on ‘Half-life Physics: radioactivity’  Radiation protection practices. Use of radioactive source, Geiger- Müller counter and smart timer.    3  Laboratory session on ‘Resistivity of metal and semiconductor’ Conduction mechanisms in metal and semiconductor, and their temperature dependence; the four-point probe method. Use of digital multimeters and DC power supplies.    4  Laboratory session on ‘Resistance of tungsten filament in a lamp andblack body radiation’ Stefan-Boltzmann law, temperature dependence of tungsten resistivity at high temperature. Use of digital multimeters and DC power supplies.    5 Laboratory session on ‘Hall effect’ The physics of Hall effect. Use of equipment including Hall probes, Gaussmeter and electromagnet.    6 Laboratory session on ‘Verification of Ampere’s Law’ The integral form of Ampere’s law. Use of Helmholtz coils and Hall probes.    7 Laboratory session on ‘Charge-to-mass ratio of electron’ Thomson’s experiment. Properties of electron, Lorentz force. Use of electron beam tube and Helmholtz coils.    8 Laboratory session on ‘Verification of Faraday's Law’ The physics of Faraday's Law. Use of digital oscilloscope, coils and magnet.   9 Laboratory session on ‘Damped oscillator, forced oscillator and resonance’ The physics of damped and forced harmonic oscillators, resonance, solutions of second order differential equation. Construction of a LRC circuits, use of digital oscilloscope, digital multimeter and LRZ meter.   10 Short test on use of equipment     Learning OutcomesBy the end of the course, students will be able to:   1 develop general considerations for the design of a scientific experiment   2 gain experience of using standard equipment to perform a measurement   3 acquire the ability of collecting, analyzing, handling and plotting of data, and estimation of errors by using Excel   4 know how to write a concise scientific report   5 acquire skills in problem solving, team work, computer usage, and planning a measurement   6 recognize the connection between theories and real-life measurements, and appreciate the principles taught in the lecture courses in introductory University Physics. Definition of a scalar and a vector in terms of transformation matrix. Elementary scalar and vector operations. Differentiation and integration of vectors. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 1)      2.         Newtonian mechanics of  a single particle   Newton’s laws. Equation of motion. Conservation law. Energy.  Solution of simple harmonic oscillators. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 6)     4.         Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics   Degrees of freedom and generalized coordinates. Generalized momentum and force. Constraints (Optional). Lagrangian and Lagrange equations of motion. Hamiltonian and Hamilton’s equations of motion. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 5.2, Chapter 8)     6.         Motion of a system of particles   Equations of motion, momentum, energy and their conservation laws, coupled harmonic oscillators and normal modes. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 9, Chapter 12)     7.         Moving coordinate systems   Galilean transformation, accelerated reference frames, rotating frames, fictitious forces, motion on the surface of the earth, Larmor's theorem. title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Physics
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS2041 and 2051 or their equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This course emphasizes the understanding of the fundamental concepts and basic theories of thermodynamics, and the analytical skills needed to analyze various thermodynamic systems. In addition to a classical approach to equilibrium thermodynamics and their applications, essential concepts in statistical physics including the relationship between microstates and entropy in an isolated system, the Boltzmann distribution, density of states, Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions will be discussed.

Work and the first law of thermodynamics    Work in hydrostatic systems, expression of work in differential form; work and internal energy, heat and internal energy; quasi-static processes, which include the concepts of heat capacity, isothermal and adiabatic expansion/contraction.      3.   The second law of thermodynamics    Heat engine, Kelvin-Planck and Clausius’ statement of the second law, reversible and irreversible processes, Carnot cycle and Carnot’s theorem.        4.   Entropy    Entropy as a state function; thermodynamic temperature scale; entropy change for an irreversible process and a reversible process.        5.   Thermodynamic potentials    Enthalpy, Helmholtz function, and Gibbs function, Maxwell’s relations; TdS equations, heat-capacity equations and internal energy equations.       6.   Change of phase    The solid state, melting, evaporation, Clausius-Clapeyron equation, triple point and critical point.                Part II: on statistical physics   Highlights of Fundamental Concepts     1. applications of Boltzmann distribution   Examples chosen, from but not restricted to, two-level system and its physical relevance, specific heat of a gas of molecules, law of equipartition of energy      4.         Density of States   Density of single-particle states and its applications.      5.         Introduction to Ideal Fermi Gas   Fermi energy, qualitative treatment on specific heat of electrons in metals, and other properties.       6.         Introduction to Ideal Bose Gas   Possibility of Bose-Einstein condensation and its physical relevance.              Learning Outcomes By the end of the course, students will be able to:    1.         describe and explain the fundamental concepts of thermodynamics, in particular, the concepts temperature, heat, entropy and free energies.     2.         acquire a microscopic viewpoint of thermodynamics     3.         appreciate the key steps in the development of thermodynamics and statistical physics.     4.         apply the concepts in thermal and statistical physics to different systems.      5.         distinguish idealized systems (e.g, ideal gas) from real systems.     6.         solve problems in thermal and statistical physics using appropriate mathematical and numerical skills.     7.         appreciate the applications of the subject to daily examples (e.g., a real refrigerator, melting of solids).      Learning title: Electromagnetic Theory I
requirements: Prerequisite: PHYS2041 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This course covers the foundation of electromagnetic theory at the undergraduate level. Topics include electrostatics and magnetostatics in vacuum and in material media; solution of boundary value problems using the separation of variables, method of image, and multipole expansion; electromagnetic induction; scalar and vector potentials; Maxwell’s equations in vacuum and in media; basic properties of electromagnetic waves and radiation. Students should have learnt the knowledge of vector calculus before taking this course. This course lays a foundation for PHYS4041 and 4450.

title: Methods in Theoretical Physics I
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS2051 or MATH2020 or their equivalents, or permission of the instructor.
description: This course provides a survey of various analytical techniques commonly used to solve problems in theoretical physics. The following physical problems are used as examples: heat conduction, vibrating strings and membranes, waves and electrostatics. Students are advised to take the introductory calculus-based physics courses: PHYS1111 or 1113, 1122, 2041 or their equivalents before taking this course.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. demonstrate knowledge of the mathematical tools taught necessary for future studies in physics.2. manage the  techniques of analyzing and expressing a physical problem in a mathematical way, and then solving it.
syllabus: 1. Problems in heat conductionDerivation of the diffusion equation. Solution by separation of variables. Sturm-Liouville problem in general, orthogonality and completeness of eigenfunctions.2. Vibrating string and circular membrane; one-dimensional wave equationDerivation of the one-dimensional wave equation; motion of homogeneous vibrating string with fixed or free ends. Initial-value problem of the one-dimensional wave equation on the whole real line; general solution and the d’ Alembert solution. Radially symmetric vibration of a circular membrane: series solution of Bessel’s differential equation, introduction to Bessel functions.3. Problems in ElectrostaticsPoisson’s equation and Laplace’s equation in electrostatics and steady-state heat conduction.  Solution of two- and three-dimensional Laplace’s equation in rectangular coordinates with various boundary conditions.Laplace’s equation in cylindrical coordinates.Laplace’s equation in spherical coordinates: the general solution with azimuthal symmetry, series solution of Legendre’s differential equation, Legendre polynomials and spherical harmonics.4. Eigenfunction expansion and Laplace and Fourier transformsEigenfunction expansion for solving nonhomogeneous partial differential equations.Laplace transform and its applications to problems in heat conduction and vibrating string.Fourier series and Fourier transform, solution of heat conduction in infinite rod and one-dimensional wave equation by Fourier transform.

title: Physics Simulations with AI Tools
description: This is a project-oriented course on computer simulation, emphasizing the setting up of physical models, the development of algorithms for the models, data analysis and graphical techniques. The basic usage of generative AI will be introduced, and students will be expected to practice the AI tools in computer simulation. Topics include: the cooling problem, single and many particle dynamics, chaotic dynamics, random processes, wave phenomena, and electrostatic problems. There are computational laboratories for practice, demonstration and illustration of the subject matter. Students are expected to have a solid background in the introductory calculus-based physics courses: PHYS1111, 1122, 2041 and first-year mathematics course: MATH1010, and have written working computer programs before taking this course. Students are advised to seek prior advice from the instructor before enrolment.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: master various means of ‘do physics’ with the computer. gain deeper understanding of the physics learned in other courses from different angle, and experience how physics can be applied in a much broader context than it was discussed in the traditional physics undergraduate curriculum. gain experience on ‘discover’ physics in a way similar to how physicists learn in the context of research. manage basic numerical methods and apply them to solve physics problems. develop structured programming in the context of doing science.
syllabus: 1. Cooling problemEuler algorithm for solving first-order differential equations.2. Single particle dynamicsNewton 's equations of motion, numerical simulation of trajectories and planet motion., higher-order algorithms, phase space analysis, simple graphics. 3. Coupled oscillators and normal modesEquation of motion for coupled oscillators, boundary conditions, dispersion relation and normal modes. Fourier analysis.4. Wave phenomenaDerivation of linear wave equation by taking limit of a linear chain of coupled oscillators, interference, diffraction and polarization. Nonlinear oscillator and FPU problem.5. Chaotic dynamicsStudy of simple deterministic nonlinear models which exhibit complex patterns of behaviour e.g. logistic map.6. Random ProcessParticle in a box, random number generator, Monte Carlo simulation and algorithms. Random walks, simulation of self-avoiding walk, diffusion equation.7. Many particle dynamicsSimulation of dynamical behaviour of many particle systems, measurements of thermodynamic quantities and simple transport properties.8. ElectromagnetismRelaxation method and random walk method for solving Laplace's and Poisson’s equations. Finite difference time domain solution of Maxwell equations.9. Seven computational laboratories Simulating particle motion Few body problem Normal modes and wave motion Molecular dynamics simulation Electric field and electric potential Random processes Monte Carlo method

title: Introduction to Soft and Living Matter Physics
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS2041 or CHEM2300 or equivalent introductory course that covers thermodynamics, or permission of instructor.
description: This course aims to offer a quantitative introduction to the dynamics of soft matter (complex fluids, synthetic soft materials and biomaterials) and living matter (living biological systems that can self-organize, self-replicate, and adapt to the environment). Soft and living matters constitute a major part of the physical world around human beings. The large complexity, the far-from-equilibrium nature, and the rich emergent phenomena of soft and living matter present many challenges and opportunities for contemporary science across multiple disciplines. The contents of this course integrate interdisciplinary knowledge from physics, chemistry and life sciences. The course is suitable for students from physics, chemistry, life science, mechanical engineering, and biomedical engineering.

title: Practical Electronics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG2202. Pre-requisite: PHYS2041 and PHYS2711, or permission of the instructor.
description: This course provides an introduction to electronic circuits commonly used in experimental physics. It aims at providing hands-on experience on what electronic components and circuits can do. Topics include: circuit analysis, diode circuits, rectifying circuits, transistors, operational amplifiers, and logic circuits. Each topic begins with an overview of the fundamentals, followed by laboratory exercises for practice. The course ends with a short project. The course is essential for performing experimental work in senior projects and postgraduate studies. The course assumes no prior experience in electronics.

title: Topics in Contemporary Physics
description: Topics of contemporary interest will be selected both from fundamental physics (e.g., black holes, pulsars) and from physics with important applications to technology (e.g., giant magnetoresistance, blue light-emitting diodes and laser). Each will be treated qualitatively and phenomenologically. The objectives are to introduce students to the frontiers of physics, and at the same time to develop skills in heuristic understanding and explanation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge at the level of the introductory calculus-based physics courses: PHYS1111, 1122, 2041.

title: Radio Observational Astronomy
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS2711.
description: The course aims to provide students with a flavor of radio astronomy, including instrumentation and hands-on experience in data acquisition and analysis. The major types of telescopes (single-dish telescopes and interferometers), instrumentation (bolometers and heterodyne receivers), and observational strategies will be surveyed, along with examples of celestial objects targeted by each technique. PHYS3430 and PHYS3440 are independent courses from each other.

title: Optical Observational Astronomy
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS2711.
description: The course aims to provide students an introduction to the principles and techniques of observational astronomy in the optical waveband, including the principles of the telescopes and instruments, and hands-on experience of data acquisition and data analysis. The topics covered will include the motivation of observations, targets to observe, practical challenges of observations, the telescopes, instruments, detectors, imaging and spectroscopic methods, data calibration, processing, and analysis methods. PHYS3430 and PHYS3440 are independent courses from each other.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. List different types of targets of astronomical observations, their radiation mechanisms, and how they can be observed.2. Describe the practical challenges of optical observations posed by the properties of light, the atmosphere, the interstellar medium, and the limitations of current technologies, etc.3. Explain the working principles of different types of telescopes, instruments, and detectors.4. Collect, calibrate, and analyze data taken through astronomical observations.
syllabus: 1. Motivation and targets of observationsMotivation, astronomical objects to observe, and their radiation mechanisms.2. Practical challenges of optical observationsThe moving sky, effects of the atmosphere, natural and artificial light pollution, limits of observations.3. Optical telescopes and instrumentationsTypes of telescopes and mounts, angular resolution, plate scale, optical aberrations, imaging and spectroscopy instrumentations.4. CCD/CMOS Detectors and calibrationCCD, CMOS, bias, read noise, dark current, gain, flat fielding, method to measure these properties.5. PhotometryMagnitude system, filters, background subtraction, aperture photometry, curve of growth, SNR equation, PSF photometry, and calibration.6. SpectroscopySlit spectroscopy, fiber spectroscopy, integral field spectroscopy, spectral extraction, wavelength and flux calibration. 7. Hands-on data acquisition and analysisConducted in parallel with topics 4-6, practice the methods on data collection, processing, and analysis.
required_readings: 1. Observational Astronomy, 2nd Edition, by D. Scott Birney, Guillermo Gonzalez, & David Oesper. (Online access through CUHK library)2. Handbook of CCD Astronomy, 2nd Edition, by Steve B. Howell. (Online access through CUHK library)

title: Classical Mechanics II
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS3051 or its equivalents, or permission of the instructor.
description: This is an advanced undergraduate course on classical mechanics. The course covers waves in mechanical systems, fluid mechanics, special theory of relativity, and one topic from either nonlinear mechanics or dynamics of rigid bodies.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. provide a coherent picture of the physics of waves in mechanical systems, including the mathematical treatment of wave equations and general properties of solutions.2. state and describe the basic theorems and applications in fluid mechanics.3. demonstrate knowledge of relativistic effects and their theoretical treatment.4. solve mechanics problems of selected topics.
syllabus: 1. WavesWave equation of a vibrating string. Boundary conditions, normal modes of vibration and energy.Superposition. Fourier series solution of a vibrating strings. Phase velocity and group velocity. General solution of the wave equation. Behavior of waves at a junction. Impedance and impedance matching.  Waves in two and three dimensions. Normal modes of rectangular box.  Sound waves.  Power of waves. Fourier transformation analysis (optional), wave packets and uncertainty relation (optional). (Thornton and Marion Chapter 13; Crawford Chapters 2, 4, 6)2. Fluid mechanicsEquation of continuity; equations of motion for an ideal fluid.  Hydrostatics.  Rotational and irrotational flows.  Bernoulli’s theorem and its applications.  Sound waves.  Simple laminar flows of viscous fluids.  Poseuille's formula.  Surface tension.  Navier-Stokes equation. (Arya Chapter 15, Symon Chapter 8)Equation of continuity; equations of motion for an ideal fluid.  Hydrostatics.  Rotational and irrotational flows.  Bernoulli’s theorem and its applications.  Sound waves.  Simple laminar flows of viscous fluids.  Poseuille's formula.  Surface tension.  Navier-Stokes equation. (Arya Chapter 15, Symon Chapter 8)3. Special theory of relativityBasic postulates, Lorentz transformation, Lorentz contraction and time dilation, addition of velocities, twin paradox, relativistic equations of motion of a particle, relativistic momentum and energy and their applications.  Four-vector formalism. (Marion Chapter 14)4. One of the following topics up to the choice of the instructor:(4a) Nonlinear mechanicsAnharmonic oscillator and Duffing’s equation, sine-Gordon equation and solitons. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 4, Barger and Olsson, Chapter 11)(4b) Elementary Dynamics of  rigid bodiesAngular momentum and kinetic energy, moment of inertia, dynamics of rigid body in a plane, combined rotational and translational motion, Euler's equations (Thornton and Marion Chapter 11 )

State vectors and observables. Matrix representation of operators. Unitary transformation and change of basis. Measurement and probability interpretation. Uncertainty relations.  Quantum dynamics. Schrodinger picture and Heisenberg picture.     2.         Operator methods in a harmonic oscillator     Creation and annihilation operators. Algebraic solution of energy eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Oscillator under a static force, translational transformation, and momentum operator. Coherent states.Driven quantum harmonic oscillators (optional). Squeezed states (optional). Coupled oscillators (optional).     3.         Angular momentum   Rotational operation and orbital angular momentum. Fundamental commutation relations of angular momentum operators. Berry’s phase.     6.         Quantum entanglement (optional)     Entangled states and disentangled states. Projective measurements on bipartite systems. Entanglemen f pure states. Bell’s inequality.  Applications of quantum entanglement.       Learning Outcomes By the end of the course, students will be able to:    1.         state and describe the formalism of non-relativistic quantum mechanics in terms of Dirac notations.     2.         manage basic operator algebra in quantum mechanics, and to apply them to harmonic oscillator systems and angular momentum problems     3.   manage approximation concepts and methods in quantum mechanics, and apply them to study various quantum systems.      Learning Activities     [AT]Lecture[/AT]   [AT]Tutorial[/AT]   [AT]Exercise Class title: Statistical Mechanics
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS2041 and 2051 or their equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This course provides an introduction to equilibrium statistical mechanics of classical and quantum systems via the theory of ensembles. Topics include: thermodynamic potentials, review on microcanonical ensemble, canonical ensemble, open systems and grand canonical ensemble, Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics and their applications, properties of ideal quantum gases. Elementary thermodynamics and statistical physics of phase transformation and transport phenomena will also be discussed. Students are advised to take PHYS3031 or its equivalents before taking this course.

And a short review of thermodynamics.   To know what to be learnt. Recap key relations in thermodynamics     2.          Types of equilibrium systems, microstates, macrostates, and distributions.   Microstates. Recap methods of counting.      3.          The fundamental postulate of equal a priori probabilities for microstates in an isolated system in equilibrium. Microcanonical ensemble.   Idea of ensemble average. Stirling’s approximation.  Evaluations of other thermodynamic quantities.  Classical ideal gas and validity of results. Volume of high-dimensional sphere. Worked Examples.  Gibbs’ entropy formula.      4.          Boltzmann distribution. Canonical ensemble. Partition function and Helmholtz free energy.   Derivation. Mean energy. Partition function. Calculations using the partition function. Energy Fluctuations. Examples: Two-level systems, paramagnetism, harmonic oscillators, Einstein’s and Debye’s models of solids, rotational partition function.  Doing sums .      5.          Examples of classical statistical mechanics.   Classical ideal gas. Validity of classical description, thermal de Broglie wavelength.  Equipartition theorem.  Examples: Harmonic oscillators.  Maxwell’s distribution of molecular speeds, diatomic gas, etc.  Gaussian integrals. Classical non-ideal gas (optional) as an example of interacting systems.     6.          Short review on Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac distributions      (Covered in PHYS3031) The most probable distribution.  Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac distributions as the most probable distributions for non-interacting indistinguishable particles, physical meaning, Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution as classical limit.  Method of Lagrange multipliers.      7.          Single-particle states:   Non-interacting or weakly interacting systems. Density of single-particle states.     Fitting waves into a confined space, k-space, turning sum over single-particle states into integrals over k, density of single-particle states.       8.          Open systems, Gibbs distribution,      chemical potential. Grand partition function. Grand canonical ensemble.   Derivation. Grand partition function and grand potential. Calculation of other thermodynamic quantities. Fluctuations. Examples: Ideal quantum gases with Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions re-derived.     9.          Applications of Fermi-Dirac statistics.   Physics of ideal Fermi gas.  Zero-temperature and low-temperature properties.  Examples may include degenerate electron gas (metals, white dwarfs), electronic specific heat of metals, degenerate neutron gas (neutron stars). High-temperature correction to ideal gas law.  Doing integrals involving the FD function.      10.      Applications of Bose-Einstein statistics.   Physics of ideal Bose gas.  Bose-Einstein condensation and its realization.   The thermal (blackbody) radiation may be presented as an optional example.     11.      Ferromagnetism as an introduction to phase transitions   Ferromagnetism as an example of interacting systems.  Mean field approximation to Ising model.  An introduction to Landau theory of second order phase transitions.  (Optional): 1D Ising model.     12.      Introduction to non-equilibrium statistical mechanics (Optional)   Mean free path, transport coefficients.        Learning Outcomes By the end of the course, students will be able to:    1.       appreciate the connection between statistical mechanics and thermodynamics and to realize that many results in statistical physics come from the same fundamental postulate     2.       state and describe the ensemble theories in statistical mechanics     3.       carry out calculations of thermodynamic properties for typical (mostly non-interacting) physical systems using ensemble theories     4.       make connections to concepts acquired in other physics courses, e.g. thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, solid state physics and astrophysics     5.       apply statistical mechanics to ideal Fermi gas and ideal Bose gas, and to relate results to physical problems     6.      manage mathematical skills related to counting, Stirling’s formula, Gaussian integrals, summations, method of Lagrange multipliers, and integrals involving Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions     7.     manage the basic principles for further studies on the statistical title: Electromagnetic Theory II
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS3041 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This is an advanced undergraduate course on electromagnetic theory. The course aims at introducing concepts of classical electrodynamics, especially electromagnetic waves and radiation and their applications, in various situations at the undergraduate level. The concepts of energy, momentum and angular momentum of electromagnetic fields will be introduced as a basis for understanding the properties of electromagnetic waves. Optical phenomena such as reflection and refraction, absorption and dispersion of light, will be explained. The retarded potentials will be derived as a solution to Maxwell’s equations and applied to illustrate the generation of radiation by moving point charges, as well as electric and magnetic dipoles. The relation between electromagnetism and special relativity is discussed.

title: Solid State Physics
requirements: Pre-requisite/Co-requisite: PHYS3021 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This core course aims at providing students with the essential concepts of solid state physics and an understanding of the properties of matter. The properties of solids are discussed using skills and concepts acquired in the fundamental subjects in physics. The course thus also serves to illustrate how physical concepts can be applied to explain the various properties of solids. Topics include: crystal lattices and structures, wave diffraction and reciprocal lattice, lattice vibrations, thermal properties of insulators, metallic behavior and free electron gas, energy bands, semiconductor physics and devices, magnetic properties, dielectric properties, and superconductivity. This is a capstone core course (subject matter) normally taken in final year of study. Students are also recommended to take PHYS3022 before taking this course.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. describe and explain the basic physical properties of crystalline solids and the underlying physics2. illustrate how physics works in the context of solids3. employ the knowledge for going deeper into the subject in the future and for self-learning of other topics not covered in the course4. appreciate the far-reaching contributions of physics to mankind, within the context of solid state physics5. make use of qualitative arguments and physical concepts (developed in different fundamental subjects) to the understand of the properties of solids6. gain experience on peer-learning
syllabus: 1. Heat capacity of solidsEinstein and Debye’s calculations, Born-von Karman boundary condition (SHS 2; CK 5; JDL 7.5)2. Metallic behavior and free electron gas How far one can get in explaining metallic behavior using a free-electron model?  Fermi energy, Fermi wavevector, density of states, plasmafrequency (comparison with experiment), heat capacity, conductivity, optical properties, Hall effect, thermal conductivity (SHS 3, 4; JDL 1, 2, 12; CK 6, HPM 6)3. Crystal StructuresCrystalline periodicity, Bravais lattices, description of crystal structures, some typical crystal structures, (optical: quasicrystals), a short review on crystal binding (SHS 12, 6; CK 1, 3; JDL 10; HPM 1, 2)4. Wave diffraction and the reciprocal latticeBragg law, reciprocal lattices, diffraction of waves by crystals (Laue condition), structure factor, brief introduction to experimental techniques (SHS 13, 14; CK 2; HPM 3; JDL 4.4)5. Lattice vibrationsHeat capacity of insulators, Einstein model and its inadequacy, normal modes, monatomic linear chain, diatomic linear chain, atomic vibrations in three dimensions (brief) , Brillouin zones, phonon dispersion relations,  relation to speed of sound (elastic waves in solids), idea of phonons (the notion of describing low-energy excitations of a many-body system by fictitious (quasi) particles), counting modes (density of states), Debye model, anharmonic effects (thermal expansion and thermal conductivity of insulators), inelastic neutron scattering (SHS 9,10; JDL 7; CK 4;  HPM 5);6. Energy bandsPeriodic potentials, electron states in crystals, nearly free electrons, tightly bounded electrons, band structure, semi-classical equation of motion of Bloch electrons, conductor, semiconductor and insulator (SHS 15, 16; JDL 11, 13, 14; CK 7, (part of)9; HPM 7) (Optional/Brief: photonic crystals, inadequacy of single-electron approaches)7. Basic semiconductor physics and devicesTypical band structure, band gap, effective mass, holes, intrinsic behavior and extrinsic behaviour (SHS 17; JDL 15, CK 8, HPM 10), p-n junction and applications (I-V curve, LED, laser,  photodetector, (brief) transistors)  (SHS 18; JDL 16; HMP 10), (brief) exciton8. Magnetic propertiesDiamagnetism, paramagnetism, spontaneous magnetization and ferromagnetism (SHS 19, 20; JDL 5; CK 11, 12; HPM 11)9. Dielectric MediaPolarization of dielectrics, local electric field, Clausius-Mossotti formula, frequency dependence of dielectric constant, (brief) ferroelectrics (JDL 3, 4; HMP 12; CK 16)10. SuperconductivityThe phenomena of superconductivity; qualitative discussion of Cooper pair and BCS theory; Electrodynamics of superconductors, London equations (JDL 6, CK 10, HPM 13)

title: Methods in Theoretical Physics II
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS3051 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This course provides students with the essential mathematical physics background needed for carrying out postgraduate studies in physics. Topics include complex analysis: analytic functions, Laurent series, Cauchy-Riemann conditions, Residue Theorem and its applications; ordinary differential equations: Frobenius method, singular points, hypergeometric ODE, Bessel equation and Bessel functions; partial differential equations: eigenfunction expansions and boundary-value problems; inhomogeneous ODE and PDE: Green’s function method.

title: Computational Physics and Machine Learning
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHYS5160. Pre-requisite: PHYS2061 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: Unlike a course in computer science or programming, this course is intended to provide a solid training in the computational techniques for the analysis and modelling of physical systems. It focuses specifically on methods for solving various physics problems. Topics include: basic numerical methods, numerical methods in linear algebra, numerical methods for ordinary and partial differential equations in physics, brief introduction to machine learning in physics.
outcome: 1. To learn through direct experience the use of modern computers in thinking creatively and solving problems in physical science. 2. To advance the development and organization of thinking about physical systems in a manner compatible with advanced computational analysis.3. To use the graphical capabilities of modern computers to visualize numerical solutions in highly interpretable forms. 4. To instill attitudes of independence and organization, which are essential for mastery of complex systems.5. To use programming to deepen the understanding of physical systems. 6. To understand why hard work and even properly functioning and powerful software and hardware do not guarantee meaningful results. To always be aware that there are limits to the accuracy possible with finite machines and to the applicability of our models.
syllabus: 1. Basic numerical methodsBriefly reviewed: Interpolations and approximations. Differentiation and integration. Zeros and extrema of a single-variable function.2. Numerical methods in linear algebraBriefly reviewed: Matrices in physics, basic matrix operations, linear equation systems, eigenvalue problems, optimization.3. Ordinary differential equationsMain topic and project. Ordinary differential equations in physics, e.g. Newton's equation of motion. Atomic scale simulation4. Partial differential equationsBriefly reviewed: Partial differential equations in physics, e.g., diffusion.5. Monte Carlo simulationSecond major topic and project: Sampling and integration. Applications in random systems, e.g. island nucleation6. Molecular dynamics, parallel computing, and Density functional theoryThe basic concepts will be briefly discussed7. 7 computational laboratories (3 hours each) for two programming projectsProject A: Atomistic scale simulations: (1) simulation cell (2) reciprocal lattice and neighbor list and periodic boundary conditions (3) potentials (4) optimizationProject B: (5) monte carlo method (6) machine learning in physics (7) Parallel computing
required_readings: 1. Computational Physics. K. H. Hoffmann and M. Schreiber (Ref no. in library: QC32 .C65 1996)2. Tao Pang, “An Introduction to Computational Physics”, Cambridge University Press, New York, 1997. (Ref no. in library: QC20.7.E4 P36 1997)

title: Physics in Meteorology
requirements:
Pre-requisite: PHYS3011.
Students who have taken course on vector calculus-based physics or their equivalents may also seek course teacher's permission to register in the course.
description: This course provides an introduction to the physical principles in meteorology, weather observation and forecasting. Topics include: physics of fluids; dynamic meteorology; atmospheric thermodynamics; atmospheric physics (cloud and lightning); weather systems and phenomena; weather observation, analysis and forecasting; climate change. Trips to Hong Kong Observatory headquarters/ outstations will be arranged to acquaint students with the operation of meteorological instruments and the real-life practice of weather analysis and forecasting.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. comprehensively understand the major physical principles underlying meteorology2. apply the basic knowledge of physics to obtain better appreciation of various weather systems and phenomena affecting our daily life3. manage the basic operational principles of weather observation, analysis and forecasting
syllabus: 1. Physics of Fluids of the AtmosphereOverview of the basic concepts and equations of the atmosphere as a thin layer of fluid covering the earth, including: the composition of the Atmosphere, Navier-Stokes Equation in a rotating frame, Coriolis force, ideal gas law, hydrostatic equation, shallow water equation, vorticity and divergence.2. Weather Systems and PhenomenaLow and high pressure systems, thunderstorm, tropical cyclone, tornado3. Dynamic MeteorologyGeostrophic and Gradient winds, geopotental height and thickness, conservation laws, waves in the Atmosphere, including Rossby wave, gravity wave, shallow water wave, acoustic wave.4. Atmospheric ThermodynamicsRadiation laws and energy balance in the Atmosphere, thermodynamics of dry air, thermodynamic of moist air, stabilities of the Atmosphere, thermodynamic diagrams.5. Atmospheric PhysicsCloud physics and atmospheric electricity.6. title: Astrophysics
description: This course provides an introduction to modern astronomy and cosmology. Topics include: star formation and pre-main sequence evolution, main sequence stars, post-main sequence evolution: red giants, white dwarfs, supernovae, neutron stars and black holes. Students should have basic knowledge in mechanics, quantum mechanics and thermal physics (PHYS3011, 3021, 3031) before taking this course. Students are advised to seek prior advice from the instructor before enrolment.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. describe and explain the basic concepts of galactic/stellar formation and evolution, compact objects, and cosmology2. demonstrate the ability to further pursue these topics in depth3. apply the knowledge acquired from other courses (eg, quantum physics, statistical mechanics, electromagnetism etc) to study various astrophysical systems

Compact stars & black holesWhite dwarfs, the Chandrasekhar limit, cooling of white dwarfs, neutron stars, pulsars, black holes

title: Topics in Nanoscience and Technology
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS3021 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This course covers the theories and applications of materials with a length-scale of nanometers. The selected topics focus on phenomena spanning from nano-electronics to nano-photonics. Topics include: growth and fabrication of nano-size materials, applying quantum physics to semiconducting heterostructures and quantum dots, band theory and its application to photonic and plasmonic crystals, physics and applications of nano-photonics and plasmonics, and applications of perturbation theories to nano-electronics and nano-photonics. The contents may differ from year to year, depending on available expertise.

title: Optical Physics
requirements: PHYS3041 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
description: This course provides an overview of the basic principles and applications of various branches of modern optics physics. Topics covered include: geometrical optics, waves optics, polarization, Fourier optics, introduction to laser physics and nonlinear optics.

title: Relativity
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHYS3041 or its equivalents, or permission of the instructor.
description: This course serves as an introduction to the central ideas of the theory of general relativity. The theory of special relativity is also reviewed and its geometric formulation will be introduced. Topics in the theory of special relativity include: Lorentz transformation, relativistic kinematics and dynamics, spacetime interval. Elements of differential geometry such as metric, vectors, covariant differentiation and curvature will also be introduced. Topics in the general theory of relativity include: gravity as spacetime curvature, geodesic equation, Einstein’s equations, Schwarzschild metric, black holes, gravitational waves, and cosmological models.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. describe and explain the basic concepts and foundation of special and general  relativity2. analyze and solve problems in relativistic mechanics3. manage the basic concepts of differential geometry required in general relativity4. analyze physics in curved spacetime5. identify important applications of relativity and explain strong-gravity physical phenomena
syllabus: 1. Review of special relativityPrinciples of special relativity, Lorentz transformation, experimental basis (cf standard University Physics textbooks)2. Special relativistic mechanicsSpacetime interval, Minkowski metric, 4-vectors, relativistic kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum, spacetime diagram (cf Cheng’s Ch 3; Hartle’s Ch 4-5; Schutz Ch 2)3. Gravity as geometryEquivalence principle, gravitational time dilation, Newtonian gravity and motion in spacetime description (cf Cheng’s Ch4; Hartle’s Ch 6)4. Description of curved spacetimeMetric tensor, local inertial frames, vectors in curved spacetime (cf Hartle’s Ch 7)5. Particle orbits in spherically symmetric spacetimesGeodesic equation (derived from the variational principle for free particle motion), Schwarzschild spacetime (not derived), particle and light ray orbits, classic tests of GR (cf Cheng’s Ch 6-7; Hartle’s Ch 8-10)6. Nonrotating Black holeLocal proper time vs Schwarzschild coordinate time, gravitational redshift, r=2M coordinate singularities and the event horizon (cf Cheng’s Ch8; Hartle’s 12)7. Basic differential geometryTensors, covariant derivative, Christoffel symbols, geodesic equation (geometric viewpoint), Riemann curvature tensor, Bianchi identities and Einstein tensor (cf Cheng’s Ch 13; Hartle’s Ch 20-21)8. Einstein equationTidal force as the curvature of spacetime, equation of geodesic deviation, energy-momentum tensor and local conservation law, principle of general covariance, Einstein equation and its Newtonian limit, Schwarzschild solution (cf Cheng’s 14; Hartle’s Ch 21-22; Schutz’s Ch 8)9. Gravitational wavesLinearized Einstein equation, propagation of gravitational waves (GW), production of weak GW, quadrupole formula and GW sources, detection of GW (cf Cheng’s Ch 15; Hartle’s 16 & 23; Schutz’s Ch 9)10. Special topics (if time is allowed)Cosmology (cf Cheng’s Ch 9-10; Hartle’s Ch 17-18; Schutz’s Ch 12), rotating black holes (cf Hartle’s Ch 14-15), relativistic stars (cf Hartle’s Ch 24)

Structured and mostly accurate exposition of material in reports and presentation. Good teamwork skills.   C : Demonstrate evidence of achieving some learning outcomes. Unclear project goal(s). Insufficient planning and ineffective implementation of the project. Satisfactory structure and mostly accurate exposition of material in reports and presentation. Fair teamwork skills.   D :. title: From Computational Physics to Artificial Intelligence
requirements:
For students in PHYS-MPHD, MSEG-MPHD, PHYS-MSC, BSc Physics;Prerequisite: PHYS3061 or PHYS4061 or sufficient programming skills in PYTHON and/or C. 
The registration of the course requires a permission of the instructor.
description: This is an introductory level course for postgraduate students on various computational techniques and concepts of artificial intelligence adopted in the field of computational physics. This course provides an opportunity for students to learn and apply the artificial intelligence related techniques learned in the lecture to various research related projects. To prepare for this course, students are expected to have taken undergraduate level computational physics (PHYS3061 or equivalent) and have grasped fundamental skills in computer programming. The course will cover random processes, linear and nonlinear regression, clustering, neural network methods, machine learning applications in physics, and other advanced artificial intelligence topics such as Generative AI, large language model, etc. The student is expected to conduct several related programming projects and deliver a final presentation.
outcome: Good Understanding of important artificial intelligence related algorithms in physics Development of the ability to apply artificial intelligence related algorithms in research project  Improvements in present skills of research project in a clear, concise, and logical manner. Enhancement of the understanding in the general concepts of computational physics Improvements of programming skills and parameter tuning abilities that are critical in computational physics research.

title: Fundamentals of Classical Mechanics and Special Relativity
requirements: For students in MSc Physics
description: This is a graduate-level introduction to classical mechanics and special relativity for Master of Science students. The course covers: Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations and applications, relativity and spacetime, and relativistic mechanics. Optional topics include: nonlinear dynamics and chaos, continuum mechanics, and Hamiltonian-Jacobi theory.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. state and apply the concept of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formalism of mechanics 2. demonstrate knowledge of relativistic effects and their theoretical treatment 3. solve mechanics problems of selected topics

title: Fundamentals of Modern Quantum Mechanics
requirements: For MSc Physics
description: This course explores essential concepts and methods of modern quantum mechanics at the postgraduate level for Master of Science students. Topics covered include: Postulates of quantum mechanics, quantum state evolution and quantum measurements, path integral approach, and selected topics in modern applications of quantum mechanics.
outcome: 1. To learn the formalism of quantum mechanics. 2. To learn the quantum dynamics of basic quantum systems such as two-level systems and harmonic oscillators. 3. To learn modern applications of quantum mechanics.
syllabus: 1. Quantum randomness and wave-particle duality2. Schroedinger wave equation3. Dirac kets and operators in quantum mechanics4. Formalism of quantum mechanics5. Angular momentum6. Quantum dynamics7. Adiabatic evolution and Berry phase8. Quantum entanglement and applications9. Supplementary modern topics (see download area)

title: Principles of Thermal and Statistical Physics
requirements: For students in MSc Physics
description: This is a graduate level introduction to thermal and statistical physics for Master of Science students. This course intends to cover laws of thermodynamics, statistical basis of thermodynamics, ensemble theory, and Fermi and Bose gases. Optional topics include interacting systems, quantum statistics, non-equilibrium dynamics, and phase transitions.
outcome: 1. To learn the fundamental concepts of thermal and statistical physics.2. To apply the concepts to different systems such as simple gases, Fermi and Bose systems.3. To learn modern applications of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.
syllabus: 1. Principles of Thermodynamics: the laws of thermodynamics, heat, work, and internal energy, entropy, potential, ideal and real gases, heat engines and refrigerators, the mathematical structures of the theory of thermodynamics such as Maxwell relations. 2. Principle of Statistical Mechanics: macro and micro states, probability theory, ensemble theories on micro-canonical and canonical ensembles, Boltzmann distribution, partition function, density of states, examples such as spin-1/2 paramagnet.3. Bose gases: black body radiation, Debye theory, Bose-Einstein condensation.4. Fermi gases: electron gas in a magnetic field, magnetism.5. Statistical mechanics of interacting systems: van der Waals equation (optional).6. Quantum system: density matrix (optional).7. Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena: order-disorder phase transitions, Ising and other models, mean field theories (optional).

title: Classical Electromagnetic Theory
requirements: For students in MSc Physics
description: This graduate level course covers basic principles of electromagnetism for Master of Science students. Topics include: Maxwell’s equations, conservation laws, electromagnetic waves, potential theory, and electromagnetic radiation.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: Apply Maxwell’s equations to describe basic electromagnetic systems. Make use of electromagnetic potentials to solve Maxwell’s equations. Calculate electromagnetic radiation from simple radiating systems.  Appreciate the role of special relativity in electromagnetism.
syllabus: Electrostatics, magnetostatics and electromagnetic induction Maxwell’s equations Conservation laws in Maxwell’s theory Electromagnetic waves in vacuum and linear media Potential theory and retarded solutions  Radiation from time-dependent localized sources Special relativity in electromagnetism

title: Computational Physics
requirements:
For students in MSc Physics;Pre-requisite: A prior programming class or sufficient programming skills in PYTHON and/or C.
The registration of the course requires a permission of the instructor.
