description: Unlike a course in computer science or programming, this course is intended to provide taught postgraduate students a solid training in the computational techniques for the analysis and modelling of physical systems. It focuses specifically on methods for solving various physics problems. Topics include: basic numerical methods, numerical methods in linear algebra, numerical methods for ordinary and partial differential equations in physics. Students are suggested to have taken at least one course in programming prior this course.
outcome: 1. To learn through direct experience the use of modern computers in thinking creatively and solving problems in physical science.2. To advance the development and organization of thinking about physical systems in a manner compatible with advanced computational analysis.3. To use the graphical capabilities of modern computers to visualize numerical solutions in highly interpretable forms.4. To instill attitudes of independence and organization, which are essential for mastery of complex systems.5. To use programming to deepen the understanding of physical systems. 6. To understand why hard work and even properly functioning and powerful software and hardware do not guarantee meaningful results.  To always be aware that there are limits to the accuracy possible with finite machines and to the applicability of our models.

title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg;For students in BSc Physics
description: This course will discuss various theoretical topics of non-relativistic quantum mechanics at the graduate level. The quantum mechanics of many-body systems will also be introduced. Topics covered include: operator methods in quantum mechanics, addition of angular momenta, variational method, stationary perturbation theory, time-dependent perturbation theory, scattering theory, and introduction to the quantum theory of many-body systems.
outcome: 1. To further appreciate the basic principles of quantum mechanics, the axiom formalism, the superposition principle, and the quantum measurement principle. 2. To appreciate the foundation of quantum mechanics, with knowledge of some modern quantum physics concepts such as entanglement, quantum no-cloning theorem, the Bell inequalities, and the EPR paradox. 3. To understand the importance of symmetry in physics, to establish the relations between quantum transformations and symmetry transformations, and to connect the conservation laws to symmetries in the quantum mechanic formalism. 4. To learn systematically the general angular momentum, spins, angular momentum addition, and relations to selection rules. 5. To learn the formalism of quantum mechanics of identical particles, especially the second-quantization formalism and the (anti-)symmetrical states, and to carry out simple calculations of many-body systems. 6. To carry out perturbation calculation of near-degenerate systems and time-dependent perturbation calculation, and to understand the linear response theory. 7. To learn concepts and formalism of scattering, to carry out calculation of single-particle potential scattering in some simple cases, and to understand the concept of resonances. 8. To learn basic concepts of adiabatic evolution, geometrical phases, and the gauge field theory. 9. To learn the basic path-integral formalism of quantum mechanics.
syllabus: 1. Formalism of Quantum Mechanics2. Review of some elementary applications3. Two- and three-dimensional potentials; angular momentum; spin4. Approximation methods (e.g. variational method, perturbation theory, etc.)5. Scattering Theory6. Many-body systems
required_readings: Please refer to Recommended Readings.
recommended_readings: 1. L.E. Ballentine, Quantum Mechanics: a modern development (World Scientific, 1998).2. P.A.M. Dirac, The Principles of Quantum Mechanics, 4th ed. (Oxford University Press, 1967).3. K. Gottfried, Quantum Mechanics, Vol. 1: Fundamentals (Benjamin, 1979).4. L.D. Landau and E.M. Lifshitz, Quantum Mechanics, Non-relativistic Theory, 3rd ed. title: Topics in Theoretical Physics (Advanced Statistical Mechanics)
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
description: This course provides an introduction to the major ideas and methods in equilibrium statistical mechanics as well as in nonequilibrium statistical physics. Topics will be selected from the statistical mechanics of magnetic systems; interacting fluids and soft matter; theory of critical phenomena and the renormalization group; stochastic dynamics and nonequilibrium processes; introduction to quantum statistical mechanics; and other topics of current interest in statistical physics.
outcome: 1. To appreciate the universality of critical phenomena. 2. To understand the key concepts in modern statistical physics including order parameter, symmetry breaking, elementary excitations, and emergent phenomena. 3. To learn the formalism of quantum statistics. 4. To understand the roles of long-range fluctuations in phase transitions and critical phenomena, the scaling hypothesis, the decimation method, and the concepts of renormalization group.  5. To carry out calculation of thermodynamic functions for interacting systems with statistical mechanics techniques such as cluster expansion, mean-field approximation, and renormalization group method. To understand the limitation of the mean-field approximation. 6. To understand basic concepts of topological phase transitions and topological excitations. 7. To acquire knowledge about typical statistical mechanics models such as non-ideal gases, alloys, liquid crystals, quantum magnetism models, Ising models and exact solutions, and two-dimensional classical spin models.
syllabus: 1. Review of basic principles of statistical physics2. Quantum statistics, (reduced) density matrix, entanglemaent3. Non-ideal gas, cluster expansion of dilute interacting gases (classical systems)4. Mean-field theory, phase transition5. Symmetry breaking, order parameter6. Collective modes and statistical fields7. Landau-Ginzburg phenomenological theory8. Fluctuations, scaling, critical phenomena9. Perturbative and lattice renormalization group10. Topological phase transitions11. Linear response theory (optional)12. Introduction to quantum phase transition (optional)

title: Topics in Theoretical Physics (Introduction to Many-body Theory)

Pre-requisite: PHYS4021, 4031, 4050 or their equivalents, or permission of teacher.
description: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and theoretical techniques of the quantum theory of many-body systems at zero-temperature as well as at finite temperature. Topics covered include: second quantization, Green's functions at zero-temperature, Green's functions at finite temperature, perturbation theory and Feynman diagram, equations of motion of the Green's functions, linear response theory, and applications of many-body theory in condensed matter physics.
outcome: 1. To learn the essential properties of Fock states and coherent states. 2. To understand and apply the rules of canonical quantization. 3. To acquire the methods of second-quantized field theory for non-relativistic many-body problems.
syllabus: 1. Second Quantization  2. Statistical Mechanics and Ideal Gas 3. Green’s Function and Feynman Diagram I4. Green’s Function and Feynman Diagram II5. Finite Temperature Green’s Function and Feynman Diagram I6. Finite Temperature Green’s Function and Feynman Diagram II7. Fluctuation-dissipation theorem and linear response theory8. Electron Gas and Landau Fermi Liquid I9. Electron Gas and Landau Fermi Liquid II10. Superconductivity I11. Superconductivity II12. Fractional quantum hall effect

title: Topics in Theoretical Physics (Introduction to Particle Physics)
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
description: An introductory survey of major ideas and important results in particle physics. Topics include symmetries groups and conservation laws, relativistic quantum mechanics, perturbation theory, quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, weak interactions, the Standard Model, gauge symmetry, spontaneous symmetry breaking, Higgs mechanism, neutrino oscillations.

title: Topics in Theoretical Physics (Advanced Computational Physics)
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
description: This course is intended to provide a solid training in the advanced techniques of contemporary computational physics. Topics covered include: classical Monte Carlo method and applications, algorithms in matrix operations and ODE PDE solvers, many-body system optimizations, A brief introduction to Density Functional Theory, random systems, and selected topics of current interest in computational physics.

title: Topics in Theoretical Physics (Quantum Optics)
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
description: Concept of photons, properties and applications of nonclassical light, photo-detection of optical coherence, photon-atom interaction models, quantum theory of damping, laser theory, atom coherence effects, and an introduction to quantum communication.

title: Topics in the Frontiers of Physics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
description: Topics of contemporary interest will be selected both from fundamental physics and from physics with important applications to technology. The objective is to introduce students to the frontiers of physics. The level of presentation assumes basic understanding of undergraduate physics.

title: Topics in the Frontiers of Physics (General Relativity)
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
description: This course provides an overview of the theory and applications of general relativity. Topics covered include: tensors, metric description of curved spaces, parallel transport and Riemannian geometry, Einstein gravitational field equations, the Schwarzschild solution and classical tests of general relativity, introduction to cosmology, cosmological models, inflation as well as some advanced topics.

title: Topics in Theoretical Physics (Astrophysics)
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics, MSc Physics or MPhil-PhD Materials Science & Engineering
description: This is a graduate course which covers various topics in theoretical astrophysics in one of the following areas: (1) Plasma physics and its applications in astrophysical phenomena, (2) Astroparticle Physics. For area (1), basic concepts in plasma physics such as plasma waves, shocks, MHD instabilities and magnetic reconnection are introduced. In addition, illustrations from astrophysics such as solar flares, cosmic rays, interstellar turbulence, and protostellar disks will be discussed. For area (2), current topics in Astroparticle physics including Big Bang nucleosynthesis, content and dynamics of the Universe, Cosmic rays, Neutrino astrophysics, and Dark matter will be discussed, with emphasis on how fundamental processes at the particle level impact astrophysical and cosmological evolution. In both areas, experimental and observational studies will be discussed in parallel with basic theory.
outcome: For Area (1):1. Understand the definition of plasma and various models aiming to describe plasma with different degrees of approximation.2. Know which models to apply for various astronomical environments.3. Understand astronomical phenomena based on plasma physics.4. Apply plasma physics to other fields.For Area (2):1. Understand the content and the evolution of the Universe.2. Have a basic understanding of particle physics, including particle interaction and detection.3. Understand various phenomena and puzzles in the astrophysics and cosmology.4. Understand how particles are used as a tool to probe various phenomena, including some modern applications.
syllabus: For Area (1):1. Basic concepts: Definition of plasma; astronomical examples; Debye shielding; quasi-neutrality.2. Vlasov, two-fluid and MHD models: Distribution function andVlasov equation; two-fluid equation; MHD equations; flux squeezing.3. Motion in a non-uniform magnetic field: adiabatic invariants; drift equation; WKB method.4. Plasma waves: Small-amplitude waves; Alfven waves; two-fluid model of Alfven modes; MHD waves.5. MHD shocks and instability: Nonlinear steeping; shock thickness; shock waves; energy principle; interchange instability; Parker instability; magnetorotational instability.6. Collision: Fokker-Planck equation; the fluid equation; transport effects; the Braginski equation.7. Collisionless plasma: Dispersion relation for cold plasma waves; parallel/perpendicular propagation; Faraday rotation; Bremsstrahlung; thermal effects; ion acoustic wave; Landau damping; resonances.8. Nonlinear phenomena Wave-particle interactions; wave-wave interactions; mode decay; nonlinear Landau damping; Kolmogorov turbulence; MHD turbulence.9. Magnetic reconnection on solar surface and molecular clouds: Sweet-Parker model; Uzdensky model; Petschek’s model; Non-MHD reconnection; Hall reconnection.10. Dusty plasmas in protostellar disks: Dust charge; dust acoustic waves; dust ion acoustic waves; crystallization.For Area (2)1. Standard Model of Particle Physics: Basic properties of fundamental subatomic particles and their possible interactions; detection of particles.2. Big Bang Cosmology: Overview of the content and dynamics of the evolution of the universe; expansion of the universe.3. Big Bang Nucleosynthesis: Production of light elements in hot Big Bang; constraints on fundamental interactions and particle content.4. Cosmic rays: Fermi acceleration; astrophysical shock waves; Cosmic-ray propagation; measurement of cosmic rays.5. Neutrino Astrophysics: Stellar neutrinos; supernova neutrinos; high-energy astrophysical and cosmogenic neutrinos; neutrino oscillations; neutrino experiments.6. Dark matter astrophysics and cosmology: Observational evidences of dark matter; cosmological structure formation; direct and indirect detection.7. Optional current research topics: Supernovae (types and observational signatures; mechanisms and dynamics); CMB B modes; dark energy models; inflationary cosmology; etc.

description: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and applications of quantum information and quantum computation. title: Modern Atomic Physics
requirements:
For MSc Physics
For MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
For MPhil-PhD Physics
description: This course will discuss various fundamental topics of modern atomic physics at the postgraduate level. The first part of the course focuses on atomic structures, the semi-classical theory of atom-light interactions and their application to the understanding of laser cooling and related topics. The second part is on atom-atom interactions at ultracold temperatures, including its application to evaporative cooling for reaching quantum degeneracy. An advanced topics section is also included to introduce the most recent developments in this field. Students should have undergraduate level Quantum Mechanics before taking this course.
outcome: 1. To apply the fundamental knowledge of quantum mechanics to understand atomic structures. 2. To understand interactions between light-atom, and atom-atom and to solve common real-world problems. 3. To understand the physical basis of the recent development in ultracold AMO physics.
syllabus: 1. Review of quantum mechanics: Schrödinger’s equation, probability density, operator and Hamiltonian, observables, uncertainty principle, angular momentum, spin. 2. Atomic structure: Hydrogen atom, fine structure, hyperfine structure, alkali atoms, Zeeman Effect, Stark Effect. 3. Atom-light interaction: Einstein coefficients, driven two-level systems, Rabi frequency, density matrix and optical Bloch equations, relaxation, saturation and lineshape, Doppler-free laser spectroscopy. 4. Laser cooling and trapping: Scattering force, slowing of atomic beams, optical molasses, cooling limits, magneto-optical trap, optical dipole trap. 5. Ultracold collisions, evaporative cooling: Introduction to scattering theory, partial wave expansion, scattering length, elastic scattering, inelastic collisions, evaporative cooling. 6. Bose Einsten condensation of dilute atomic gases: Critical temperature, condensate fraction, macroscopic wave function, Gross-Pitaevskii equation, Thomas-Fermi approximation.

recommended_readings: 1. Christopher J. Foot, Atomic Physics, Oxford University Press, 2005, ISBN 0-19-850696-1. 2. Harold J. Demtröder, Laser Spectroscopy: Basic Concepts and Instrumentation, 2nd Edition, Springer-Verlag, 1996, ISBN 3-540-57171-X. 4. Marcis Auzinsh, Dmitry Budker, Simon Rochester, Optically Polarized Atoms: Understanding light-atom interactions, ISBN-13: 978-0199565122.

title: Introduction to Biophysics
requirements: For students in MSc Physics, MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg or MPhil-PhD Physics
description: Biophysics investigates biological phenomena using theoretical and experimental approaches derived from physics, such as statistical mechanics, fluid mechanics, and optics. This course provides an introduction to biophysics for postgraduate students with no biology background. Students will be introduced to basic biology and physics concepts relevant to the course, followed by topics including the functions of biomolecules, dynamics of regulatory networks, physics of cellular behavior, and recent development of frontier biophysics techniques. Through this course, students will become familiar with the scope and basic approaches of biophysics research, learn how to perform computer simulations on biomolecules, and develop interest in exploring new territories of biophysics. Students should have undergraduate level thermodynamics and statistical mechanics before taking this course.
outcome: (1) To understand basic concepts in biophysics. (2) To develop knowledge of commonly-used methods in computational and experimental biophysics research. (3) To develop interest in applying physics concepts and tools to study living systems.
syllabus: 1. Introduction to biology: Proteins and other biomolecules inside cells; Central dogma of molecular biology; Types of cells.2. Basic concepts in biophysics: Friction and diffusion; Energy, entropy, Brownian motors; Water as the solvent for life; Viscosity and low-Reynolds number world.3. Molecules, machines and mechanisms; Enzymes and molecular machines; Membranes and machines in membranes; Bioelectricity and nerve impulses.4. Techniques in biophysics research: Computer modeling and simulation; Molecular dynamics simulations; Commonly used programs and force fields; analysis of simulation results. A brief survey of single-molecule techniques.
required_readings: Please refer to Recommended Readings.

Jackson; Cambridge : Cambridge University Press, 2006. 4. Machinery of Life [electronic resource] / by David S. Goodsell. New York, NY : Springer-Verlag New York, 2009.

title: Topics in Experimental Physics (Thin Film Physics and Technology)
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
description: This course provides an introduction to the physical properties of thin films as well as the preparation methods. Topics covered include: vacuum science and technology, thin film deposition techniques, growth processes and modes, characterization, epitaxy, lattice engineering, optical and electrical properties of thin films. State-of-the-art scientific research on thin film preparation and properties will also be selectively introduced.
outcome: (1) To know the technologies that involve thin films. (2) To understand the basic principles of vacuum science and technology that are related to thin-film deposition techniques. (3) To understand the thermodynamics of evaporation and learn the basic principles of evaporation. (4) To acquire the basic knowledge about adsorption, surface diffusion, nucleation, and structure development that are involved in thin-film deposition. (5) To acquire the basic knowledge of epitaxial deposition. (6) To learn the basic knowledge of chemical vapor deposition. (7) To learn the basic techniques of measuring the physical and chemical properties of thin films.

title: Semiconductor Physics and Devices
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
description: This course discusses the physics of semiconductors and the principles behind selected applications. The physics of the electronic band structures, electrons and holes dynamics, effects of impurities, semiconductor statistics, and lattice vibrations will be discussed, using the technologically important semiconductors such as Si, Ge, and GaAs as examples. Transport properties and optical properties of semiconductors will then be treated. The principles of some common devices based on semiconductors will be introduced. The physics of selected semiconductor heterostructures will also be discussed. Using semiconductors as the context, the students will learn and appreciate how quantum physics, statistical physics, and elementary solid state physics can be applied to understand much of semiconducting materials, which have transformed and will continue to transform technologies and the world.
outcome: 1. To apply fundamental knowledge in quantum physics, statistical physics, and  solid state physics  to understand the technologically important semiconducting  materials;2. To develop a comprehensive understanding of the physics of semiconductors and a physical sense on why semiconductors are useful;3. To apply physical principles to understand the physics behind  typical semiconductor devices;4. To apply physical principles to understand the physics behind low dimensional semiconductor heterostructures and their applications.
